clinical_study.brief_title: Convalescent Plasma as Potential Therapy for Severe COVID-19 Pneumonia
clinical_study.official_title: Convalescent Plasma as Potential Therapy for Severe COVID-19 Pneumonia

lead_sponsor.agency: Centro de Educación Medica e Investigaciones Clínicas Norberto Quirno

clinical_study.source: Centro de Educación Medica e Investigaciones Clínicas Norberto Quirno

brief_summary.textblock: To determinate feasibility, safety and outcome with convalescent plasma in patients with severe COVID-19 penumonia

detailed_description.textblock: COVID-19 convalescent plasma will be infused to patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia to determine feasibility, safety and clinical outcome efficacy by survival at-28 days. Data will be compared with match control arm patients without plasma infusion

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: patients with severe COVID19 pneumonia will be recruited to a single arm therapy group with convalescent plasma from recovered patients

primary_outcome.description: number of subjects surviving at 28 days from plasma infusion

secondary_outcome.measure: efficacy of plasma infusion according to antibodies levels in the infuse bags
secondary_outcome.description: comparison of clinical efficacy according antibodies levels

secondary_outcome.measure: clinical efficacy of plasma infusion according to frame time from symptoms onset and hospitalization
secondary_outcome.description: we will search if clinical efficacy is better when the earlier the infusion is decided

secondary_outcome.measure: change in clinical WHO ordinal scale from 1 to 10 points
secondary_outcome.description: WHO clinical scale is a measure of patient progression through the health-care system with 1 point asymptomatic patient and 10 patient dead

arm_group.description: patients with severe COVID19 pneumonia defined by: spontaneous breathing patients with respiratory failure requiring O2 nasal cannula more than 3 L/min or reservoir oxygen mask and SaO2 less than 95% or patients with critical pneumonia define by mechanical ventilation with less than 300 mmHg PaO2/FiO2 or shock or multi-organic dysfunction

intervention.description: intravenous infusion of 300-600 mL of convalescent plasma with an antibody title more than 3 according to chemiluminescent microparticle immunoassay (Architect Plus Abbott)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients ≥18, and non-pregnant women
- Severe or critical COVID-19 disease define by one or more of the following: blood oxygen saturation ≤ 94% on supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula at least 3 L/min, non-rebreathing mask (NRO2-mask) or on noninvasive ventilation; and pulmonary infiltrates with >50% increase within 24 to 48 hours in chest-X-ray or chest CT. Life-threatening disease was defined as one or more of the following: respiratory failure on mechanical ventilation with PaO2 / FiO2 less than 300 mm Hg, septic shock, and/or multiple organ dysfunction.
- 10 days from the onset of symptoms or ≤ 7 days on mechanical ventilation. -
Exclusion Criteria:
- More than 10 days from symptoms onset or more than 7 days on mechanical ventilation
- Pregnancy
- Contraindication for plasma infusion because anaphylaxis history
- Patients with high risk of circulatory overload
- Limitation of therapeutic efforts
- Refractory shock define by norepinephrine dose more than 1 ug/k/min
- SOFA score more than 15 points at the moment of the protocol inclusion i Coagulopathy with requirements of plasma infusion
